citations.title: [Social media for air quality perception]( (Atmospheric Environment, 2019)
[Twitter for wildfire smoke detection]( (Scientific Reports, 2020)
[LLMs for Information Extraction in Scientific Text]( (arXiv, 2023) — General LLM extraction
[Multimodal Foundation Models]( (arXiv, 2023) — General multimodal LLMs
[Smell Pittsburgh]( — Citizen odor reporting platform (could be data source)
[Data Quality in Citizen Science]( (Nature Sustainability, 2021) — Quality control challenges
[LLMs for Anomaly Detection]( (arXiv, 2023) — General LLM anomaly detection
[Conversational AI for Health]( (npj Digital Medicine, 2020) — Health chatbots
[Explainable AI for Environmental Data]( (Environmental Modelling & Software, 2021)
[Scientific Discovery with LLMs]( (Nature, 2023) — LLMs for hypothesis generation
[Environmental Justice and Air Quality]( (Science, 2020) — Disparities in pollution exposure
**PurpleAir**: [API access]( 100k+ sensors, includes user comments
**Smell Pittsburgh**: [Public data]( odor complaints with text descriptions
**OpenAQ**: [Global air quality data]( mostly sensor data
1. **[Using Social Media to Measure Air Quality Perception]( (Jiang et al., Atmospheric Environment 2019) — Social media for air quality (pre-LLM)
2. **[Data Quality in Citizen Science]( (Kosmala et al., Nature Sustainability 2021) — Quality control challenges
3. **[Scientific Discovery with LLMs]( (Boiko et al., Nature 2023) — LLMs for hypothesis generation
4. **[Smell Pittsburgh: Crowdsourcing Air Quality Reports]( — Citizen odor reporting platform (potential data source)
[PurpleAir Network]( — Citizen air quality sensors
[OpenAQ]( — Global air quality data aggregator
